page.description: Covers a number of topics relating to variables. Topics include: using operators and calculating values, Xbasic operators, using variables inside HTML tags, outputting variables, and more.

section.title: Using the DIM Statement
section.description: When creating an A5W page you use the DIM statement to create new variables.
section.example: <%a5 dim cFirstname as C = "Fred" dim nAge as N = 12 dim dBirthday as D = {08/03/1992} dim lMarried as L = .F. dim tWhen as T = ctodt("08/03/1992 3:23:34 pm") %>

section.title: Case Is Irrelevant
section.description: Alpha Anywhere and the Xbasic programming language do not care whether variable names are upper or lower case, or even a mixture of the two. The follow three statements are identical in functionality.
section.example: <%a5 dim clastname as C dim cLASTNAME as C dim cLASTname as C %>

section.title: Naming Variables
section.description: There are several guidelines for naming variables.

case.description: Make the names meaningful, so that you can understand what they are. Length is not a problem, but longer names invite spelling errors.
All names should begin with a letter (A..Z or a..z). You can also use numbers and underscore "_" characters. Do not use spaces or other symbols.

Many programmers also prefix a variable name with a tag that indicates the variable's type (character, numeric, logical, etc.). This helps to avoid programming errors. For example: Lastname becomes cLastname and Quantity becomes nQuantity , indicating that the first is a character variable and the second is a numeric variable.
Do not use any of the reserved words as variables. This will always cause program errors.

section.title: Outputting Variables
section.description: The following page displays different types of variables. Note how the DIM statements also assign values to the variables as they are created.

step.description: Create a new A5W page with the following content.

case.example: <%a5 dim cFirstname as C = "Fred" dim nAge as N = 12 dim dBirthday as D = {08/03/1992} dim lMarried as L = .F. dim tWhen as T = ctodt("08/03/1992 3:23:34 pm") ? "His name is " + cFirstname + ". " ? "He was born on " + dBirthday + " at " + time("h:m AM",tWhen) + ". " ? "Since he is " + nAge + " years old, it is not surprising that he " if (lMarried = .F.) then ? "is not" else ? "is" end if ? " married." %>

case.description: The character variable cFirstname has an initial value of "Fred". Note how the ordinary HTML text and the tag are combined with the cFirstname variable using the plus "+" character and output with a single question mark "?" at the beginning of the line.
case.example: dim cFirstname as C = "Fred" ... ? "His name is " + cFirstname + ". "

case.description: The date variable dBirthday has an initial value of {08/03/1992} and the tWhen variable has an initial value of 3:23:34 pm (after reformatting by the CTODT() function). Note how the single output statement prints both the dBirthday and tWhen variables. Since the HTML page wants a character value to display, we use the TIME() function to convert the time value to a formatted character string.
case.example: dim dBirthday as D = {08/03/1992} dim tWhen as T = ctodt("08/03/1992 3:23:34 pm") ? "He was born on " + dBirthday + " at " + time("h:m AM", tWhen) + ". "

case.description: Next, we print out the nAge variable. No special formatting is required.
case.example: dim nAge as N = 12 ? "Since he is " + nAge + " years old, it is not surprising that he "

case.description: Finally, we test the value of the lMarried variable, and make a decision about which of two character strings to output.
case.example: dim lMarried as L = .F. if (lMarried = .F.) then ? "is not" else ? "is" end if ? " married."
